text: And we're going to tell you a little bit of a story of observability So in this story we've got four chapters So we've got the first which is the fairy tale of finding and fixing a problem Then we're going to go on an epic debugging journey with our favorite man Sid The expert of DevOps Victor tells us about his grand Kubernetes expectations And finally we're going to teach you a little bit about the observability onion as we like to call it But first our fairy tale of finding and fixing a problem Once upon a time there was an ogre called Shrek And Shrek lived happily alone in his swamp Life was good in the swamp Everything worked as expected There was peace and quiet Shrek was happy and nothing disturbed his equilibrium Until one day that started like any other Shrek heard a noise What could that be he thought to himself He gets up from his dinner and finds there's someone in his bed Okay This is an easy enough problem to solve He grabbed the intruder and swiftly kicked them out But when he opened his front door panic There are more creatures everywhere disrupting his peace All the things he feared the most are happening His once peaceful house was now overrun and he didn't know why He tried his usual I'm a scary ogre routine to no success It solved a lot of his problems before Whatever happened it was going to take some hard work to fix To get his swamp back he first needed to understand what was going on After chatting with some of the fairy tale creatures he finds out that Lord Farquaad is responsible for sending all those pesky creatures to his swamp He'd found the root cause of his problem Shrek just needed to talk to him and ask him to send the creatures somewhere else An easy fix Shrek and his friend embark on this epic journey to Lord Farquaad Shrek understood his swamp well but this journey took him to some brand new places He spent a lot of time trying to understand and exactly what he is looking at And he also fought some completely pointless battles Finally he found Farquaad He learned that the fix wasn't quite as simple as he'd hoped To get Lord Farquaad's help Shrek actually needed to rescue a princess from a So once again he journeyed through dangerous territories Any step could have been fatal He got distracted by a very dangerous looking dragon that actually ended up not being a dragon He got burnt He got hurt But eventually he managed to find the princess And on the long journey home Shrek learned about her He thought that maybe returning her to Farquaad wasn't the best solution to his problem Maybe he should take the princess back to his swamp They could get rid of the fairy tale creatures together Or perhaps he could share his swamp with her and their new fairy tale friends But unfortunately Shrek overheard a conversation that sounded like it confirmed his original suspicions With this new information he returned to his original plan After he returned the princess to Lord Farquaad Shrek had realized he'd made a big mistake His problems weren't actually solved So once again he had to fight With the help of his new friends Shrek re rescued the brought her back to his swamp and they lived happily ever after The end So what's the moral of our story here What's Shrek actually got to do with observability Two Things are often good until they aren't You may not actually be solving the problems you need to solve And finally knowing how to find and interpret the information is crucial to solving your problems Just like debugging your case controllers And hopefully we can pull this together a little bit more during our talk and you can understand why Shrek is so important to observability But first I'm Kat Morris I'm product manager at We build Craddocks and I'm here with Derek Yes I'm Derek I'm a software engineer at Cintasso building Craddocks And we are here to talk about title again from planning to peace making Kubernetes controllers observability so class Because at the end of the day Craddocks is a controller that's what we build and we learn a lot through the journey So our first chapter well second chapter after our lovely fairy tale is Sid's epic debugging journey So I'd like you to turn your mind back to 2024 And in November one of my greatest joys as a product manager is I get to spend a lot of time with our customers Not just hearing about their problems but also the solutions they have to those problems too And in November 24 I was invited to a community of practice event And this community of practice was all about how this customer was using Craddocks how they were implementing the functionality and some things they learned about the product And this is Sid He was one of the main users at the time and still is He's one of our favorite guys gives loads and loads of feedback and has lots of strong opinions about how the product should work And he was giving a demo If you haven't found Sid yet you can bump into him He lives in Edinburgh He's an amazing walker He does crazy walks What's that 19 2 kilometers Insane So have a chat with Sid He's a fun guy but he was doing a demo of debugging So in this debugging demo it was how do I figure out something that's gone wrong in Craddocks and how do I fix it So the demo of debugging It started with creating a test promise And for those of you who don't know Craddocks you don't need to know it in detail but a promise is just a CRT So we created a test one which had something broken in it All good First thing you do it's not try to show what happened with the promise It's to show the seven Kubernetes related aliases that he had set up in his system These are long commands that it's hard to remember So we have to set up aliases to make it easier to use Kubernetes Not a great start for me as a product manager It doesn't get much better So Sid then applied the promise CR Which is really hard to see what's happening because you just get a CR applied Not very informative So we set up a watch on the controller logs And if any of you know Kubernetes controller logs it was something like this which is super unhelpful in figuring out what's actually happened So okay That's not the easiest thing to use How about instead of the controller logs I look at the pod logs Fine Find the pod name Get the logs Have a look They're pretty cool However the pod name changes So you can't just look at the pod name Fine More work We'll add a label to the container so that I can consistently get the container logs Great There's a label on there I can look it up every time Fine Next thing he wanted to show us was Kate's events So what's actually happening over time What things are getting fired off This is when I realized we were missing some key capabilities in the product Because Kubernetes logs are great but we have a whole product We should be firing things that are more relevant to So put a pin in that one We'll come back to it We're only halfway through folks There's a whole other section of this Number seven Next Lists all the pods and checks all the errors Because it's not just one pod that gets fired There are multiple Each of those get their own labels and get their own view on the board And we realized he's a broken promise So now he greps for errors And this is another watch on that command So we have about four different windows open at this minute just to find one debugging scenario And this is the bit that made me really sad Because he added a weight to the container to find the problem in a little bit more detail So we're getting through a lot of information and having to do a lot of actions to fix a problem And then he showcased our troubleshooting guide which told you this exact thing and this is how you should a terrible job This is such a bad user experience Because it took him 12 steps to finally fix and reapply this promise CR And I thought is this the experience we want for our customers Is this really what we want to happen Probably not And it's showing that knowing how to find and interpret that information is crucial to solving a problem So let's recap on SID's pains there Because pains are always helpful to think about and how you solve your problems Lots of long Kubernetes commands that are hard to He had to alias them Not ideal Nonpredictable resource names means it's really hard to figure out what's the thing you want to look at You've got to look in several places to find the root cause of your problems and actually get to the bottom of an issue And once you have that's still hard because there are a flood of repeated logs which is classic for Kubernetes because of reconciliation loops and other stuff that Derek is going to talk about now and show how we fixed it Because we need to improve it So how can we All right So let's just recap on the pain The first pain is interacting with the platform And it's how your user is actually going to get that information that they need And what we thought about to solve this problem is giving our users different interfaces So the first one is the one that we all know about and the one that SID was using which is kubectl which is you know the queen It should always work And this is like the standard way that users can interact with your platform And it has many ways like with selectors and labels and gets and describes All those commands should work They should be able to get any information that they need However as you could see by the seven aliases sometimes it's hard Sometimes it's long I think I bet many of you do a control R and then try to find that particular command you run or you start or some other tool to be able to figure it out So what else can we do We can build a CLI A CLI is another terminal based tool We all love them But it allows you to actually parse and grab and find the exact same like piece of information that you want to display to your user with colors with highlights with anything that you need I think there is some very successful CLIs out there like Tekton For the ones of you that are familiar with Tekton it's a pipeline tool It's a tool to run workflows on top of Kubernetes And instead of making you understand the entire data model what they do is they provide you with a CLI that you can just say Tekton run pipeline And then it will actually go and create the necessary resources and pull the logs and show you that information there The biggest problem with CLIs is that it's another thing to learn Our users are I'm not saying lazy but they usually don't want to learn and yet another thing to be able to interact with the platform And furthermore oftentimes they don't even have access to those things because they run in completely different environments and they cannot download and install it So what else are you going to do You can build a GUI Yay That's probably you right Like we are all hardcore engineers We all really like our terminals our DMUX our NeoVims And trust me I'm with you I don't actually want to build this thing I don't like React I don't like JavaScript I'm like the person next to you I'm allergic to it However are some very good tools out there like Headlamp which is an open source tool part of CNCF that gives you a way to build interfaces on top of Kubernetes that don't suck that much And that's kind of what we did There is a lot of purple in this screenshot That's our branding But we built a tool on top of Headlamp that allows you to quickly get an at glance view of what's going on in the world And that's the thing that that GUI actually gives you is that at glance view You can quickly go and see what's going wrong So if you look at it there's like something is red You don't need to be very smart or understand a lot about products to see this is kind of where you need to look right And it also allows you to explore The other thing that a GUI like this provides is links is tabs is things that you click and you can actually know where to go You don't need to understand the data model to be able to explore what's going on in the system So that's the first one interacting with the platform is hard And we have the second thing which is all logs are hard to But why is that Why is it hard to get logs right So let's go through what happens when a user apply a promise A bunch of Kubernetes resources we don't need to care about them all But when the user apply a promise it triggers a promise controller And let's assume there is a log line over there How many times that same log line will be logged Well anytime that any of these resources change for what reason whatsoever because all of those things will trigger reconciliation and promise controller So all of a sudden when you have like a single log line what does that mean It means there will be loads of them loads of the same log line In fact here's an exploration that we did with a customer And I don't know if you can read it but we managed to log almost 3 000 lines within a two minute window And our customers actually raised an issue It was like there's probably something wrong with my platform I don't understand why this spike And it's just because we are logging it So what can you do Log less Thank you That's the end No just kidding So let's take a look at the log lines again right Like this is a snippet of code that we have in CRUDX And you can see in the all of the log lines And some of those log lines are useful like I'm suspending job for the manual reconciliation Some of them are maybe less useful like checking status of the list pipeline So who cares is the question that you should ask yourself Is it operators Is it the users Is it developers or just you And what are you using those logs for Is it a heartbeat Just you know like okay my system is alive If you debug an issue and something is wrong we need to understand what's going on Or is it just like I got here sort of log lines that are left when you are debugging and writing your code This is yes It's all of it for all of them So what can you actually do about it You can include log levels Very basic but it was surprising how much we had to work to come up with the idea of maybe we should have some log levels So this is the same diagram that I had before but you know whiteboard in our office And then we came up with the very surprising industry standard log levels of error warning for debug and trace And each one of those things each one of those levels are configured for the user and it meant for a different persona that is using your system The second thing you can do to reduce your log lines is just reconcile less So what if instead of having this is again a snippet of code of This is the work controller which owns the work placement as you can see over there And what happens is every time that our work placement changes this controller will be reconciled QBuilder if you use QBuilder it gives you a way to control when you're actually going to do the reconciliation So we build throughout our controllers a bunch of that say okay only trigger the reconciliation when this particular change the status or this particular condition or this particular thing happens to my sub resources So that will dramatically reduce the number of times that the work controller will reconcile which means less log lines You can add also add some structure If you add structure to your logs your users can hook in into Elasticsearch or some other tools and get them sampled to get them a little bit easier to like queryable in a better way So it's not only humans that are going to read your logs but machines are also going to read them And finally Kubernetes a bunch of things will go wrong but not all errors are actually errors So if you're trying to get something and you don't find maybe try again in the next reconciliation Do you need to log that line Because that will be noise There will be more things that are going to send your users like Shrek to the wrong direction searching for like fighting your own battles So we applied all of those to our resources and we were able to reduce the number of logs in a promising install by 67 percent I actually did the math which is pretty good There are still hundreds of log lines It's still a work in progress We're still trying to get it like to just the absolute basics but now the user can control and reduce it a little bit more So that's chapter two So chapter three is Victor's grand Kubernetes expectation So we're going forward a bit in time now over to January 2025 Our team has come back from holiday We had a lovely Christmas We've had our New Year's party Everyone's feeling nice and merry and a little bit fat then one of our colleagues posts into one of our Slack channels Drumroll everybody Nope There we go This video by Victor on the AI and DevOps toolkit So if you've seen it it's probably not new to you but he does a lot of great videos on the CNCF ecosystem DevOps tooling He did one and it came out on the 30th of December So forgive us for not catching it immediately which was about Crow And Crow is a tool that provides abstractions on top of Kubernetes resources Sounds quite a lot like what our product does but on a bit of a smaller scale a bit more Kubernetes focused than we are we watched this video and his basic his findings were the product is quite immature It's actually hard to do a lot of stuff on it and the logging isn't quite there So as product manager I was thinking okay he's got opinions on this Our product does something in this same wheelhouse If he was part of our team what would Victor Farsik do But actually I was more worried about him picking up our product and giving it a go and trying it So what would Victor Farsik expect of Kubernetes And Chinyu you're going to hate me You're back on screen again So I sent one of our top Cates engineers and if you were here yesterday you could have watched our talk I was like we've got this video by Victor Farsik Could you watch it Give me a summary of what he says and what that would mean for us and what would we have to do differently Because I want to make sure that if he does do a review of our video I'm not going to get embarrassed if he does something talks about our product So why might we have been a little bit embarrassed here So Derek told you a little bit about logs but if we think about the user of our product you've got a platform engineer back to this diagram they're going to apply a promise Not crazy But look at all of that stuff that's in the picture there There's a lot of concepts that are more native to our product more native to Kubernetes experts You shouldn't need to understand these things to be able to successfully debug a problem However let's say the work placement goes down It doesn't matter what it is You've got all of these different levels to go through to try and find out where your problem is How is that platform engineer if we don't expect them to know what all of those things inside the platform cluster are how are they going to figure out what went wrong How are they going to fix it Because things are good It's fine applying a promise It's fine interacting with your platform It's good Until they aren't And when they aren't first thing you're going to do is kubectl describe And this is what we figured out How can a user find the broken component And this is where we thought about the problem here So a single apply may create many resources This is really complicated It can spin off a bunch of other different things which means it's hard to go all the way back because you don't understand the relationship between them It's not a simple system Kubernetes isn't a simple system How can a user figure out what's going on when any of those intermediate resources could also fail And then finally how can that user debug and fix the issue when you've got all of these other problems and they don't understand the internals of your system So Chinyi gave me a review I was very excited about the track of work We don't know if this guy still hasn't spoken about our product but I won't be embarrassed if he does now And Derek's going to show you why Why I'm proud now All right So the pain that we had here or the challenge that we're trying to determine is like to fix this the data that the user needs to fix whatever is broken is hard to find We didn't even know what exactly we needed to expose though So that's actually our first problem What do we need to expose So what we did was go back to the personas So we have different people that use our software and different actors in the system We have people writing a promise people using the platform So who is the data for What is the data that we want to expose and who is it for So we considered those two things and came up with a few design principles So from any resource to its sub resources So if something deep down buried down five resources deep fails we should be able to find a line that tries it back to the resource that the user is interacting So when there is a promise if the promise creates a job the job creates a pod the pod creates a work the work creates a work placement you should be able to find that thread from the promise because that's what they are interacting with It should be unsurprised for kubectl users Yes we have our interfaces we have our CLIs but users using the kubectl they should be able to do gets and describes and still get the information that they need get the events and the bits and bobs that they need in there We should have a clear state indicators for all the products resources So what we didn't have before we had resources that have some status saying I'm ready some status saying nothing no status or like status saying that they're available So we should be able to see quickly for all the resources that we have if it's ready if it's healthy if it's like something is broken with them And to do that we come up with some consistent status fields So if the user knows what you expect if they know that there will be a key called ready or available or healthy it makes it easier for them one less thing for them to learn about your system And finally whenever that state changes we want it to be tracked through events So Kubernetes in Kubernetes you can emit events and in those events we're going to track all of the state changes What does that mean in practice Well a bunch of stories So happily we delivered them all It's not that bad We probably left removed a few of them from the it was come up with like common labels So the first thing we did was well if the user is using the kubectl let's make sure that the resources has some common labels so you can track things across So for example a promise is the resource that the platform writer interacts with platform engineer interacts with and that creates a bunch of other resources So if you add a label with the promise name to all of those sub resources it makes it a little bit easier for them to find who created that Furthermore Kubernetes exposes user CRDs There is a CRD CR And in there there is a lot of things that you can do to make it easier for users to interact with your platform like additional printer columns and validations Additional printer columns is basically what allows you to extend what the user gets when they run kubectl get on the terminal So this is an example of a change we made So in the top we had the work placements The work placement basically gets a work puts you into a destination and that can succeed or fail So before the changes we had age which is the default thing that you get And then we extended that like okay let's add some information there that the user can quickly see where it is and if it's ready or not So maybe none of you understand CRDs that well but you can understand what's going on in the second screenshot for sure And to do that we also need some status and conditions So Kubernetes has a sub resource called status as most of you know And there is an API convention doc that goes into a lot of details This is a it has 2 000 lines in about what you expect from your resource spec what you expect in resource status and conditions So we went through that doc We read through them all without any AI whatsoever And we came up with some status and conditions for all of our resources So this is a promise So you can see this when you run describe and you have things like work succeeded it has reconciled successfully the pipeline succeeded and it's available So we now at quick glance the user can see what and when was the last thing that happened And as we talked about before we also did some events So whenever some of those conditions change we emit an event So the user can also do kubectl events or kubectl describe and see exactly when and how what happened at that particular point in time and how many times it happened They can also hook in their dashboard and monitoring system into those events and be notified when things change And this actually saves us a lot of time So I joke that the best thing we're building in Kratix was destination status It saves us a lot of time So destination is basically a point into a Git repo And for that and you'll be amazed by how many people cannot encode a secret in Kubernetes or have a new line So be able to quickly say okay get destinations and say I cannot write to this datastore It was a life changer All right So we've told you a lot there and we're going to bring it all together with my favorite concept which is the observability onion And the observability onion kind of encapsulates this thought of you may not be solving the problems you actually need to solve because it's not just a single thing that you can look at There are lots of layers And this is why I told you about the story of Shrek in the beginning because ogres are like and observability is also like an onion What do I mean So at the center you've got the lowest level the locks They're going to be really helpful for people who are like understand the low level concepts that you're doing and you can configure stuff in it Not always the most helpful but you can build upon it into statuses What's green What's red What's working What do I need to fix But to use a status then you have to go into low level detail and have a look at all of your different resources So you build it up the next layer into events How can I know at the point of time when something goes wrong Can I get it fired at me so that I know when to look into the things rather than having to continually check it But metrics are like the next level up from that So the event telling you when things go wrong but how do I know I've met my SLAs How do I know my system has the uptime I expect You put all of those events together into your metrics to see how your platform is actually performing And traces take that to the next level So you've got your metrics of a long period of time but what does this look like over the time period of a failure What do the other services and systems look like What are my series of events doing before a thing went wrong and after a thing went wrong so I know what other impact that problem had But these are all kind of low level systems You can take it up one more level into your interfaces So we gave you lots of different interface options before This is really good at basically sharing that information out Do you as an engineer need a GUI Maybe not But your operations team might love one because they really care about those traces over time And an observability GUI makes it your stakeholders are going to be super interested in the metrics of your platform How does it perform So getting that interface with all those lower levels can make it much easier for each of the people who are interested in your platform or interested in the observability of your be successful So this is our summary slide I have no time to go through all of the So please take a photo if you want But we'll also be sharing the slides of all the things we've summarized today And we did promise that we would have AI in here somewhere Oh but we promised AI We didn't actually talk about AI We realized we completely ran out of time So we did ask AI to come up with our observability onion for us and it failed So if you need better observability to actually make a better image next time open AI let me know I've got a whole talk on it So thank you very much for listening to us today You can come visit us at our booth I'm not sure we have time to question because we definitely overran So come chat to the booth if you want to know anything We'll be around all day Thank you

buried down five resources deep fails we should be able to find a line that tries it back to the

the job creates a pod the pod creates a work the work creates a work placement
you should be able to find that thread from the promise because that's what they are interacting

We should have a clear state indicators for all the products resources So what we didn't have

for all the resources that we have if it's ready if it's healthy if it's like something
is broken with them And to do that we come up with some consistent status fields So if the
user knows what you expect if they know that there will be a key called ready or available
or healthy it makes it easier for them one less thing for them to learn about your system
